Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Package Signing] Add Service Bus Integration between Validators and Jobs" (#4810) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Unable to use `dotnet restore` behind corp firewall" (#5980) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.3.0.4406

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.0.0

VS version (if appropriate): 2015

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Windows 7

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: First time tried

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Get behind corporate proxy with .pac script

2. Create a new project. ex: `dotnet new console -lang f#`.

3. Run `dotnet restore` to repeat the same error shown in step 2.

Expected: All referenced packages to be restored without error

Actual: The following error occurs.

> Response status code does not indicate success: 407 (authenticationrequired).

## Other suggested things

I've tried setting up a NuGet.config file in my project directory which looks like it is being read because when I get bad syntax it complains. But when I have everything in there that looks right I still get the same error.

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
    <config>
         <add key="dependencyVersion" value="Highest" />

        <add key="http_proxy" value="http://<my_org_proxy_domain>:9090" />
        <add key="http_proxy.user" value="<my_user>" />  
        <add key="http_proxy.password" value="<my_encrypted_password>" />
    </config>
</configuration>
```

### Verbose Logs

[dnrestore.log](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1352438/dnrestore.log)


### Possibly related issues

https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/2190
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5358
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5078
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/4668
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/2880

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Use NuGet with different Culture" (#5976) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: VS UI

VS version (if appropriate): Visual Studio Community 2017 version 15.3.5

Worked before? No.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Control Panel > Clock, Language, and Region > Region ;

2. In "Format" ComboBox, select "Hebrew (Israel)";

3. Click on "Additional settings..." in the bottom of the window;

4. In "Date" tab, in the "Calendar" section, in "Calendar type" ComboBox, select "לוח שנה עברי";

5. Click on "OK" button, and than "OK" button on the first window,

6. Now, If I try Download a package (in Nuget Package Manager Or Console), I get the error:
An error occurred while writing file 'C:\Users\Oryan\Desktop\WpfApp1\WpfApp1\packages.config': Failed to write packages.config as XML file 'C:\Users\Oryan\Desktop\WpfApp1\WpfApp1\packages.config'. Error: 'Illegal characters in path.'.

\>\>I can't download packages from Nuget for VS if I using the Hebrew calendar!!!

## Other suggested things
The same problem was with the VS Installer, and they fixed it. I guess that the problem is with "DateTime.Now.ToString()" without customize some specific format for all culture.

I will be happy if you will inform me when you will fix the bug. Thanks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Accessibility] “Blocked by project” versions of SDK “Microsoft.NETCore.App” should be shown in grey instead of black" (#5948) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**VSTS ISSUE:** 484554
**NuGet Version:** NuGet 4.4.0-Dev-4438
**VS Version:** D15PreRel 26823.3006
**OS Version:** Windows 10 RS2_Release 15063.2.170323-1837
 
## Repro Steps:
New a Visual C#->.NET Core->Console App (.NET Core) project.
Open PM UI of this project and go to “Installed” tab.
Select the SDK “Microsoft.NETCore.App” in the left panel.
Click the “Version” drop-down list and check the versions.

## Expected Result:
These “blocked by project” versions should be shown in grey (same with the color of “Uninstall” and “Update” buttons).
 
## Actual Result:
These “blocked by project” versions were shown in black as below screenshot.

![attachfilehandler](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2132567/30941215-3009c9f4-a399-11e7-98fd-e49ac1b21968.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet restore fails with private feeds on MacOS Sierra" (#6003) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @felpel on October 9, 2017 3:0_

## Steps to reproduce
- Create a private feed on VSTS;
- Clone VSTS' Git repository;
- Configure `NuGet.config` accordingly:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <clear/>
    <add key="MyPrivateFeed" value="https://{myPrivateRepo}.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/{MyPackages}/nuget/v3/index.json"/>
  </packageSources>
</configuration>
```
- Call `dotnet restore`

## Expected  behavior
I should be able to restore my private feeds' packages. It works fine in a similar Windows environment.

## Actual behavior
I'm unable to restore packages from our private VSTS feeds when I call `dotnet restore`:

```
  Restoring packages for /Users/Marie-Francoise/Felix/Git/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.DataShareService/src/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.Business.Abstractions/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.Business.Abstractions.csproj...
  Restoring packages for /Users/Marie-Francoise/Felix/Git/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.DataShareService/src/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.Business.Server/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.Business.Server.csproj...
  Restoring packages for /Users/Marie-Francoise/Felix/Git/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.DataShareService/src/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.AzureFunctions/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.AzureFunctions.csproj...
  Restoring packages for /Users/Marie-Francoise/Felix/Git/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.DataShareService/src/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.DataLayer/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.DataLayer.csproj...
/usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/2.0.0/NuGet.targets(102,5): error : Unable to load the service index for source https://autovurnd.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/AutoVuPackages/nuget/v3/index.json. [/Users/Marie-Francoise/Felix/Git/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.DataShareService/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.sln]
/usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/2.0.0/NuGet.targets(102,5): error :   Response status code does not indicate success: 401 (Unauthorized). [/Users/Marie-Francoise/Felix/Git/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.DataShareService/AutoVu.SaaS.Ptms.Dss.sln]
```

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:
```
Outils en ligne de commande .NET (2.0.0)

Product Information:
 Version:            2.0.0
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  cdcd1928c9

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Mac OS X
 OS Version:  10.13
 OS Platform: Darwin
 RID:         osx.10.12-x64
 Base Path:   /usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/2.0.0/

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 2.0.0
  Build    : e8b8861ac7faf042c87a5c2f9f2d04c98b69f28d
```







_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#7788_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Expose package metadata in PM Console" (#6002) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This is not so much an issue, but more of a discussion topic. It would be nice if more of the package's metadata was exposed inside the Package Manager Console. Currently only the package ID, version and license URL are available when using Get-Package for a locally installed package for example. But we do not have other metadata, such as tags. Neither do we have the install location for the package.

The reason I'm asking is because we currently have a set of PowerShell scripts that can be run in the package manager console that handle deployment of a so called database package, which is just a NuGet package with a specific set of files. Currently I'm discovering the packages folder manually and using the old LocalPackageRepository API to get additional metadata. This has worked fine for us with Visual Studio 2015, but it doesn't work so well for 2017 and with all the changes going on under the hood (no more packages folder and packages.config) we're having trouble moving forward.

If more information would be available in the PM console when I do Get-Package that would make this a lot easier to do. Is this something worth considering?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Spurious "not added because the package already contains file" warnings" (#6001) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This is really two bugs: The files chosen automatically for inclusion when packing may contain duplicates. And, `NuGet.exe` emits warnings about the duplicates despite the user making no explicit choices.

Though these are "just warnings" it's very annoying, especially when a repo contains lots of packable projects. And, affected solutions have no workaround except completely changing the layout of their output folders.

/cc @rohit21agrawal @emgarten 
/fyi @anurse

## Details about Problem
- `NuGet.exe`
- NuGet version: `4.3.0.4406`
- OS version: `Win10 Enterprise v1703 (15063.632)`
- Worked before?: Not sure when it worked. But, it must have because the directory layout involved has been really common in our (Microsoft's) solutions.
## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
1. Clone the [aspnet/WebHooks](https://github.com/aspnet/WebHooks) repo
2. `.\build.cmd`
### Expected
Clean build
### Actual
About 130 warnings, all similar to
```
EXEC : warning : File 'WebHooks\bin\CodeAnalysis\Test\Microsoft.AspNet.WebHooks.Common.dll' is not
 added because the package already contains file 'lib\net45\Microsoft.AspNet.WebHooks.Common.dll' [WebHooks\src\Packages\Packages.proj]
```
## Other suggested things
### Likely root cause
Problem is caused by nesting of output directories and the [wildcard search](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/a19eab5a4ca5584fbf9ba091350ed797d55a5534/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/CommandRunners/PackCommandRunner.cs#L340-L341) in [`PackCommandRunner`](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/a19eab5a4ca5584fbf9ba091350ed797d55a5534/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/CommandRunners/PackCommandRunner.cs)’s `GetFiles(…)` method.

In this solution, most projects use an `$(OutputPath)` [setting](https://github.com/aspnet/WebHooks/blob/922798f6fa6c60f5876c447818b220435e74fc8f/tools/WebHooks.settings.targets#L21) to `$(WebHooksRootPath)bin\$(Configuration)\` in [`tools\WebHooks.settings.targets`](https://github.com/aspnet/WebHooks/blob/922798f6fa6c60f5876c447818b220435e74fc8f/tools/WebHooks.settings.targets). Test projects individually (e.g. [here](https://github.com/aspnet/WebHooks/blob/922798f6fa6c60f5876c447818b220435e74fc8f/test/Microsoft.AspNet.WebHooks.Common.Test/Microsoft.AspNet.WebHooks.Common.Test.csproj#L14)) set `$(OutputPath)` to `..\..\bin\$(Configuration)\Test\`. In other words, the test projects write assembly files et cetera into a subdirectory of the usual output folder.
### WebHooks\bin\CodeAnalysis content
![bin](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6431421/31312551-1d77192e-ab7b-11e7-9a09-317b771ce82c.png)
### WebHooks\bin\CodeAnalysis\Test content
![test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6431421/31312554-29107276-ab7b-11e7-8672-9ca3e7ef050a.png)
### Sample Project
- [aspnet/WebHooks](https://github.com/aspnet/WebHooks)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Build action not applying to contentFiles" (#6000) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Dear Nuget community,

I've been stuck for some time now and I need your help. I've been trying to solve a single problem: attach a .dll file to a project (as a content). I had a relatively easy way placing it as a content, but having it as an Embedded Resource just doesn't work! It places the file in the correct place, but sets the Build Action to "Content".

I've read and followed the [official documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/schema/nuspec) and placed a <contentFiles> section in the metadata, but it's still not working.

I've attached my .nuspec file (with files names changed, for privacy):

myNuspec.nuspec (changed the extension to .txt so I could upload the file):
[myNuspec.1.0.0.0.txt](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1363579/myNuspec.1.0.0.0.txt)

Bellow I've placed the data recommended:

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe
NuGet version: 4.1.0.2450
dotnet.exe --version: 1.1.0
VS version: Professional 2017
OS version: Windows 10.0.14393.1715 (v1607) [can't update]

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "<NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn> ignored on project reference" (#5999) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@mafalarz reported this issue here: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/869

<NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn> ignored on project reference

Despite adding the` <NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn>` on all my project reference like this:
```
<ProjectReference Include="..\Reports\Reports.csproj">
   <NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn>
</ProjectReference>
```
I still get the warning message 

> NU1701: Package 'Teradata.Net.Data.Provider 15.11.0.1' was restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1' instead of the project target framework '.NETStandard,Version=v2.0'. This package may not be fully compatible with your project.

Also on publishing Nugget and adding <`NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn` to my nugget package:

```
> <PackageReference Include="Carbon.ClientQueries" Version="0.0.1.16-Preview">
>       <NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn>
> </PackageReference>
```
I keep getting warning: 

> NU1701: Package 'Teradata.Net.Data.Provider 15.11.0.1' was restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1' instead of the project target framework '.NETStandard,Version=v2.0'. This package may not be fully compatible with your project. 

I think this is because my nugget has a reference to a project reference of my solution like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30442378/29490081-a77ebd2c-84ff-11e7-8c6c-e2514d4e2b71.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Markdown based documentation for packages" (#9) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Package-README.md-support|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2280|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).
